texts.shortText: Strange-looking hydroid with a very tall, rounded and extensible floppy orange to pink central part (the hydranth) with a terminal mouth and covered in densely-packed, very short tentacles. Basal part surrounded by a single ring of about 20 fairly-thick branches, those of females bearing large (ca 1 mm diameter), pink reproductive gonophores that are each ornamented with a white distal ring and longitudinal lines and with a few short, branching terminal tentacles. (male unknown).

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Luderitz to East London.

Usually found singly on the underside of boulders, or on vertical rock faces in the intertidal or in shallow reefs down to about 27 m. Also recorded on algae, including the kelp Ecklonia maxima. The elongate hydranth is very flexible and can be extended and bent laterally to search for prey, or contracted into a short cone.

Nothing else is known about the biology of this remarkable species, which is reported only from a few photographic records.

Members of this family have a mouth at the end of the central hydranth and are predatory. This species has been seen bending over and ensnaring amphipods and isopods, which are stung by the short tentacles covering the conical hydranth and then transferred to the terminal mouth and swallowed.
No details on this species, but males and females separate. In related species, anemone-like actinulae larvae are released and each have about 18 tentacles.

Easily recognized to group but can be confused with the closely-related Dreadlocks hydroid C. tentaculatum, which is mostly found in deeper water of 10-30 m depth and is often colonial and associated with the false coral bryozoan Laminopora jellyae. That species also has a white rather than pink hydranth and more elongate pink basal branches that are spotted with button-like white tentacles.

Note: Some of the images available appear to show other unknown forms and do not conform to the descriptions of either of the described local species.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 52 as C. tentaculatum).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 56 as Myriothela capensis).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 45 as Myriothela capensis).
